import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import csv
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression
import statsmodels.api as sm

source:
#method_1_using statsmodels packages
X1 = df1.iloc[:,1]
Y1 = df1.iloc[:,2]
X1 = sm.add_constant(X1) # We have an intercept in the model, so we increase the intercept
est1 = sm.OLS(Y1,X1).fit()
print(est1.summary())
Bata = est1.params
print(Bata)

#draw the picture of method 1
plt.rcParams['font.sans-serif'] = ['SimHei']
plt.rcParams['axes.unicode_minus'] = False

predicts = est1.predict() # the predicted value of the model
X1 = df1.iloc[:, 1] # the independent variable is the data in column 2
plt.scatter(X1, Y1, label='the actual value') 
plt.plot(X1, predicts, color = 'red', label='the predicted value')
plt.legend() 
plt.show()

#method2_using sklearn
from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error, r2_score
x1=df1[['positive']] #dataframe
y1=df1[['volatility']].values #numpy.ndarray
reg1 = LinearRegression()
reg1.fit(x1, y1)
print('Intercept:{}'.format(reg1.intercept_))
print('Coefficient:{}'.format(reg1.coef_))
reg1.score(x1,y1)
pred1 = reg1.predict(x1)

plt.figure()
plt.scatter(x1,y1,color="black",label='the actual value')
plt.plot(x1,reg1.predict(x1),color="red",linewidth=3,label='the predicted value')
plt.title("regression model of volatility and positive")
plt.xlabel("positive")
plt.ylabel("volatility")
plt.legend() 
plt.show()

source:
#method_1_using statsmodels packages
X2 = df2.iloc[:,1]
Y2 = df2.iloc[:,2]
X2 = sm.add_constant(X2) # We have an intercept in the model, so we increase the intercept
est2 = sm.OLS(Y2,X2).fit()
print(est2.summary())

#draw the picture of method 1
plt.rcParams['font.sans-serif'] = ['SimHei']
plt.rcParams['axes.unicode_minus'] = False

predicts = est2.predict() # the predicted value of the model
X2 = df2.iloc[:, 1] # the independent variable is the data in column 2
plt.scatter(X2, Y2, label='the actual value') 
plt.plot(X2, predicts, color = 'red', label='the predicted value')
plt.legend() 
plt.show()

#method2_using sklearn
from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error, r2_score
x2=df2[['positive']] #dataframe
y2=df2[['price']].values #numpy.ndarray
reg2 = LinearRegression()
reg2.fit(x2, y2)
print('Intercept:{}'.format(reg2.intercept_))
print('Coefficient:{}'.format(reg2.coef_))
reg2.score(x2,y2)

pred2 = reg2.predict(x2)
plt.figure()
plt.scatter(x2,y2,color="black")
plt.plot(x2,reg2.predict(x2),color="red",linewidth=4)
plt.title("regression model of price and positive")
plt.xlabel("positive")
plt.ylabel("price")
plt.show()

source:
#method_1_using statsmodels packages
X3 = df3.iloc[:,2]
Y3 = df3.iloc[:,1]
X3 = sm.add_constant(X3) # We have an intercept in the model, so we increase the intercept
est3 = sm.OLS(Y3,X3).fit()
print(est3.summary())

#draw the picture of method 1
plt.rcParams['font.sans-serif'] = ['SimHei']
plt.rcParams['axes.unicode_minus'] = False

predicts = est3.predict() # the predicted value of the model
X3 = df3.iloc[:, 2] # the independent variable is the data in column 3
plt.scatter(X3, Y3, label='the actual value') 
plt.plot(X3, predicts, color = 'red', label='the predicted value')
plt.legend() 
plt.show()

#method2_using sklearn
from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error, r2_score
x3=df3[['positive']] #dataframe
y3=df3[['production']].values #numpy.ndarray
reg3 = LinearRegression()
reg3.fit(x3, y3)
print('Intercept:{}'.format(reg3.intercept_))
print('Coefficient:{}'.format(reg3.coef_))
reg3.score(x3,y3)

pred3 = reg3.predict(x3)
plt.figure()
plt.scatter(x3,y3,color="black",label='actual value')
plt.plot(x3,reg3.predict(x3),color="red",linewidth=4,label='the predicted value')
plt.title("regression model of output and positive")
plt.xlabel("positive")
plt.ylabel("production")
plt.legend()
plt.show()

#method_1_using statsmodels packages
X5 = df5.iloc[:,2]
Y5 = df5.iloc[:,1]
X5 = sm.add_constant(X5) # We have an intercept in the model, so we increase the intercept
est5 = sm.OLS(Y5,X5).fit()
print(est5.summary())

#draw the picture of method 1
plt.rcParams['font.sans-serif'] = ['SimHei']
plt.rcParams['axes.unicode_minus'] = False

predicts = est5.predict() # the predicted value of the model
X5 = df5.iloc[:, 2] # the independent variable is the data in column 3
